metadata.title: Selective synthesis of quinazolinones by using fluorescein catalyst under mild conditions

Selective synthesis of quinazolinones by using fluorescein catalyst under mild conditions Liang Jin Conceptualization Methodology Investigation Writing – original draft Xuehua Chen Software Formal analysis Sheng Huang Validation Investigation Aixin Wang Data curation Zhongsheng Chen Visualization Zhanggao Le Project administration Writing – review & editing Supervision ⁎ Zongbo Xie Resources Supervision ⁎ Jiangxi Province Key Laboratory of Synthetic Chemistry, East China University of Technology, Nanchang, 330013, China Jiangxi Province Key Laboratory of Synthetic Chemistry East China University of Technology Nanchang 330013 China Jiangxi Province Key Laboratory of Synthetic Chemistry, East China University of Technology, Nanchang, 330013, China ⁎ Corresponding author. A fast and highly efficient method for the synthesis of functionalized dihydroquinazolinone and quinazolinone via photocatalysis has been reported. Fluorescein has respectively participated in the cyclization and dehydrogenation reactions, and different products were obtained in the presence and absence of light. 2-Phenyl-2,3-dihydroquinazolin-4(1H)-one was synthesized by fluorescein without visible light. Subsequently, quinazolinone was further obtained with the dehydrogenation of dihydroquinazolinone by fluorescein induce. The reaction process was highly efficient, and a wide range of quinazolinones could be synthesized with a highest yield of 98% in just 1 h under visible light conditions. Furthermore, the reaction could be extended to the gram level by up to 88%. This protocol provides an alternative route for preparing quinazolinone derivatives by employing photocatalytic methods for synthesizing quinazolinones without additional oxidants, acids and metals. Graphical abstaract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Quinazolinone Selective synthesis Fluorescein and Tandem reaction Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. Introduction Quinazolinone derivatives are used extensively in medicine, agriculture, and other fields. Several molecules with quinazolinone structures exhibit a wide range of biological activities (Fig. 1 ) [1–4]. Therefore, the synthesis of quinazolinone and its derivatives has received significant attention owing to their significant application prospects, such as anti-cancer and anti-malarial activity [5–7]. The classical method for the synthesis of quinazolinones involves the condensation reaction between 2-aminobenzamide and aldehyde in the present of various catalysts [8–10], including acids [11,12], metal catalysts [13,14], and oxidants [15,16] (Scheme 1 , a). However, these reactions commonly require toxic solvents [17,18], high temperatures [19,20], and relatively harsh reaction conditions [21,22]. Therefore, developing green and efficient approaches for the synthesis of quinazolinones is necessary. Some research groups [23,24] have reported efficient (reaction time: 3 min) methods for the synthesis of quinazolinone derivatives under microwave irradiation. The methods provide an effective strategy for the one-pot synthesis of complex compounds and have great potential. Recently, photocatalytic organic conversion via photo-induced electron transfer to synthesize N-heterocycles has attracted significant attention owing to its attractive advantage [25–29], such as a simple experimental apparatus, mild reaction conditions, and environmental friendliness. In 2013, Nagasawa et al. [30] reported that I2 catalyzes the production of 2-aminobenzamide and aldehydes to synthesize quinazolinone derivatives using a fluorescent lamp under O2 atmosphere (Scheme 1, b). However, the substrate scope was limited, and the reaction time was long. In addition, fluorescein has been used as a photocatalyst to synthesize quinazolinone compounds. In 2021, Xing et al. [31] reported an efficient and fast (reaction time: 2 h) method for synthesizing quinazolinones by combining p-TsOH. Later, Liu et al. [32] reported a method for the synthesis of quinazolinone using fluorescein as a photocatalyst in the present of TBHP (reaction time: 3 h). Although these methods are very efficient, reaction is limited for large-scale applications due to the requirement of strong acids or oxidants for the catalytic conditions. Therefore, an important goal of green chemistry is to develop visible light-induced tandem reactions without external oxidants [33–36]. In this study, we report a novel methodology for visible-light-assisted catalysis using fluorescein as a photocatalyst to prepare quinazolinones without acid or oxidants in good-to-excellent yields under mild reaction conditions by irradiation with blue light (Scheme 1d). Results and discussion The reactants selected in this study were 2-aminobenzamide and benzaldehyde. In the absent of 18 W Blue LEDs light, product (4a) was not obtained and dihydroquinazolinones (3a) can be obtained with a 98% yield (Table 1 , entry 1). At the same time, considering that benzaldehyde can be oxidized to benzoic acid in the air [37], when benzoic acid was added without fluorescein, the experimental results showed that the formation of product 3a was catalysed by fluorescein (Table 1, entries 1, 2). Several catalysts were investigated to determine the optimal catalyst under the 18 W Blue LED. In the present of fluorescein, the yield of 4a was 92% (Table 1, Entry 3). Only trace amounts of the product were obtained in the present of anthraquinone, 9-Fluorenone, Eosin-Y, or Ru(bpy)3Cl2·6H2O as photocatalysts (Table 1, entries 4–7). Fluorescein respectively participates in cyclization (3a) and dehydrogenation (4a) reactions, which can accelerate the formation of product 4a (Table 1, entries 1, 3). Therefore, fluorescein was determined to be the most optimal catalyst. The results of the solvent screening are summarized in Table 1. CH3OH was found to be the best reaction medium, with the highest yield (92%) (Table 1, entry 3). In the present of EtOH or dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO), the yield of 4a was 87% and 82%, respectively (Table 1, entries 8, 9). However, when reacting in these organic solvents, the target product was obtained in only moderate yields (49–75%) (Table 1, entries 10–12). The target product was barely obtained in nonpolar solvents (Table 1, entry 13). After determining CH3OH as the best medium, various light sources were examined to improve the reaction efficiency. The results are presented in Table 2 . Blue light was the best light source, with the highest yield of 92% (Table 2, entry 2). When blue light was replaced with other light sources (such as white, green, yellow, or no light), only a small amount of the product was obtained, or no product was obtained. Therefore, the light source is an important factor that influences the reaction. After investigating the effect of the mole ratio, 2-aminobenzamide and benzaldehyde were chosen at the optimal mole ratio of 1:3 (Table S1). To explore the scope and versatility of this method under dark conditions, aldehydes and amides with different substituents were selected for one-pot reactions in CH3OH. The results are presented in Table 3 . The yield of 2,3-dihydroquinazolin-4(1H)-one (3a) in the absent of light was 98%. The electron-rich 2-amino-5-methoxybenzamide provided the corresponding product 3b with a good yield (79%). Similarly, when N-methy-2-aminobenzamide is used as a raw material, the product 3c was obtained in a good yield of 89%. Using a large steric hindrance of o-aminobenzenesulfonamide as the reactant, 83% yield (3d) was obtained within 3 h. For the aldehyde part, when p-chlorobenzaldehyde and p-methoxybenzaldehyde are used as reactants, corresponding products can be obtained with high yield (Table 3, 3e and 3g, 90% and 86%). However, when halogen Cl replaces the ortho position of benzaldehyde, the reaction yield of 3f is lower than that of p-chlorobenzaldehyde (3e). M-methylbenzaldehyde also obtained a good yield (3 h, 85%). In addition, some aliphatic aldehydes were selected as substrates to study the reaction range. The desired product (3i, 84%) was successfully synthesized from cyclohexyl formaldehyde within 2 h. Similarly, the yield of pentanal was 87% (3j). Furthermore, the protocol is limited and ketone compounds are not suitable for this reaction. In order to explore the scope and versatility of this method under photocatalytic conditions, aldehydes and a series of amides with electron donating or electron absorbing substituents were selected to test the universality of the substrate for this reaction. The results are shown in Table 4 . First, under optimal reaction conditions, aldehydes and a series of amides with electron-donating or electron-withdrawing substituents were selected to test the universality of the substrate for this reaction. In the absent of substituents, 4a was obtained in 92% yield. When 2-aminobenzamide with -Cl, -Br, and –OCH3 at the 5-position was used, the products were obtained at similar yields (Table 4, 4b-4d, 76%, 84%, 78%, respectively). The suitability of N-substituted 2-aminobenzamides for this process was also investigated, and the corresponding quinazolinones were obtained in good yields (Table 4, 4e, 90% and 4f, 83%). In the present of steric effects, product (4 g) was obtained using 2-amino-N-benzylbenzamide with a yield of 69%. For the aldehyde moiety, substituting benzaldehyde with -F, -Cl, -Br, and –OCH3 gave the corresponding products in good yields (Table 4, 4 h-k, 80–98%). However, in contrast to the electron-donating effect of the methyl group, the yields of o-methyl quinazolinone (4l, 74%) and p-methyl quinazolinone (4n, 76%) were lower than those of m-methyl quinazolinone (4 m, 88%) because of the large steric hindrance of the fluorescein catalyst. Heterocyclic aldehydes were selected as substrates to investigate the reaction range, and 2-thiophene carboxaldehyde was successfully reacted to produce the desired product after 2 h (4o, 95%). Notably, the corresponding products (4p and 4q) were obtained in good yields when cyclopentanecarbaldehyde and cyclohexanecarbaldehyde were used. Similarly, valeraldehyde was obtained in a 96% yield (4r). Substrates with strong electron withdrawing groups are not conducive to the reaction, such as o-, m-, p-nitrobenzaldehyde, and p-cyanobenzaldehyde. To further explore the reaction mechanism, several control experiments were conducted (Scheme 2 ). In the absent of Blue LEDs light or fluorescein, product (4a) was not obtained (Scheme 2, a, b). Under optimal conditions, TEMPO was added to the reaction system to study the photocatalytic process. The reaction was found to be inhibited, indicating that this reaction involves a free radical pathway (Scheme 2, c). When the reaction was performed under a nitrogen atmosphere, the yield of 4a decreased to 15% (Scheme 2, d). Furthermore, Dihydroquinazolone was converted to the product in 99% yield under standard conditions (Scheme 2, f). To confirm whether the reaction involves a chain process, a “light on/off experiment” was performed. Fig. 2 shows that the continuous light source is conducive to the formation of 4a product. Based on these experimental results and relevant references on the electrochemical potential of organic molecules [38–40], a plausible mechanism for this reaction is presented in Scheme 3 . On the one hand, hydrogen bonds formed between the oxygen atom of the carboxyl group in benzaldehyde (2a) and the H atom of the hydroxyl group in fluorescein, resulting in enhanced polarization of carbonyl group of 2a [41–43]. Then, o-aminobenzamide attacks benzaldehyde to form a Schiff base, which undergoes cyclization and dehydrogenation to form dihydroquinazolinones (3a) under the catalysis of fluorescein. On the other hand, intermediate 3a was oxidized to 3a·+ by the excited state PC* with the generation of PC*¯. PC*¯ is regenerated by O2 associated with the formation of superoxide radicals (O2 ·− ). 3a·+ was oxidized by O2 ·− associated with the formation of HOO· and 4a′. Then, 4a′ reacted with HOO· giving the final product 4a and hydrogen peroxide (see the information). To explore the synthetic utility of this reaction, we performed large-scale synthesis under the standard conditions shown in Scheme 4 . We carried out large-scale synthesis (1 mmol and 5 mmol) with 2-aminobenzamide and benzaldehyde in the present of fluorescein (3 mol%), which produced 0.1977 g (88%) and 0.8791 g (79%) of the desired quinazolinone, respectively. Conclusions We developed an effective method for synthesizing quinazolinones in CH3OH under addition-free conditions. The reaction could be extended to the gram level by up to 88%. The method does not require additives or additional oxidants (except oxygen in the air), it only requires fluorescein. The method also has the advantages of high yield, mild reaction conditions, simple operation, and wide substrate applicability. Experimental section Instruments and reagents All major chemicals and solvents were obtained from commercial sources and used without further purification. 1H and 13C NMR spectra were recorded on a Bruker Avance III-500 spectrometer (Bruker, Switzerland). Photochemical reaction system was purchased from Beijing nuozhi Technology Co., Ltd Model: RLH-18, eight position parallel photochemical reaction system. The wavelength of blue light is 455 nm. The distance between the light source and the irradiation instrument is 3 cm. Procedure for the synthesis of quinazolinones derivatives Dihydroquinazolinone: A mixture of 2-aminobenzamide (0.2 mmol), benzaldehyde (0.6 mmol), fluorescein (3 mol%) and methanol (2 mL) was added to the test tube for 1–2 h under air atmosphere and stirred at 300–400 rpm. Quinazolinones: A mixture of 2-aminobenzamide (0.2 mmol), benzaldehyde (0.6 mmol), fluorescein (3 mol%) and methanol (2 mL) was added to the test tube. The reaction mixture was irradiated with a Blue LED (18 W) for 1–2 h under air atmosphere and stirred at 300–400 rpm. The reaction was monitored using TLC (PE: EtOAc = 6:1, v/v). The organic phase was concentrated under reduced pressure to give the crude product, which was purified by column chromatography to obtain the pure product. coredata.dc:description: A fast and highly efficient method for the synthesis of functionalized dihydroquinazolinone and quinazolinone via photocatalysis has been reported. Fluorescein has respectively participated in the cyclization and dehydrogenation reactions, and different products were obtained in the presence and absence of light. 2-Phenyl-2,3-dihydroquinazolin-4(1H)-one was synthesized by fluorescein without visible light. Subsequently, quinazolinone was further obtained with the dehydrogenation of dihydroquinazolinone by fluorescein induce. The reaction process was highly efficient, and a wide range of quinazolinones could be synthesized with a highest yield of 98% in just 1 h under visible light conditions. Furthermore, the reaction could be extended to the gram level by up to 88%. This protocol provides an alternative route for preparing quinazolinone derivatives by employing photocatalytic methods for synthesizing quinazolinones without additional oxidants, acids and metals.
coredata.dc:title: Selective synthesis of quinazolinones by using fluorescein catalyst under mild conditions
